questions.question: 1. What is the primary purpose of a camera matrix in computer graphics?

answers.a: To store pixel values of an image.
answers.b: To define the position and orientation of the virtual camera.
answers.d: To control the color balance of rendered images.

questions.explanation: The camera matrix is crucial in defining the position and orientation of the virtual camera in a 3D scene, determining how the scene is projected onto the 2D image plane.

questions.question: 2. In perspective projection, what happens to the size of objects as they move farther away from the virtual camera?
questions.explanation: In perspective projection, objects appear smaller as they move farther away from the camera, simulating real-world visual phenomena.

questions.question: 3. What is the purpose of the 'field of view' parameter in a camera?

answers.a: To control the depth of field in photography.
answers.b: To specify the range of colors captured by the camera.
answers.c: To determine the width of the image frame.
answers.d: To control the extent of the scene visible to the camera.

questions.explanation: The 'field of view' parameter in a camera defines the extent of the scene that is visible to the camera, influencing the framing of the rendered image.

questions.question: 4. Which type of projection is often used in architectural drawings and technical illustrations due to its simplicity?
questions.explanation: Orthographic projection is commonly used in architectural drawings and technical illustrations for its simplicity and accurate representation of object proportions.

questions.question: 5. What is the concept of 'clipping' in computer graphics, particularly in the context of camera frustum?

answers.a: It refers to adjusting the brightness and contrast of the rendered image.
answers.b: It involves removing objects outside the viewable region to enhance rendering efficiency.
answers.c: It defines the process of applying textures to 3D models.
answers.d: It signifies the adjustment of the camera's focal length.

questions.explanation: Clipping in computer graphics involves removing objects outside the viewable region of the camera frustum, optimizing rendering efficiency.
